bibl.title: Tacitus, Germanicus and the Kings of Egypt (Tac. Ann. 2.59-61).
bibl.note: A version of this paper was read in May 2008 at the Annual General Meeting of the Classical Association of Canada in Montréal. - Germanicus, Alexander and Egypt. - Germanicus and the kings of Egypt. - Tacitus, Germanicus and the Principate. - Conclusions. The Egyptian digression in Annals Book 2, though part of the tradition of the 'Egyptian voyage', should be read as part of a complicated meditation on the rise and fall of tyranny.
bibl.seg: KELLY Benjamin, Tacitus, Germanicus and the Kings of Egypt (Tac. Ann. 2.59-61).

A version of this paper was read in May 2008 at the Annual General Meeting of the Classical Association of Canada in Montréal. - Germanicus, Alexander and Egypt. - Germanicus and the kings of Egypt. - Tacitus, Germanicus and the Principate. - Conclusions. The Egyptian digression in Annals Book 2, though part of the tradition of the 'Egyptian voyage', should be read as part of a complicated meditation on the rise and fall of tyranny.
